{{Infobox company | name = Paxata | logo = File:Paxata logo.png | logo_caption = | image = | image_caption = | trading_name = <!-- d/b/a/, doing business as - if different from legal name above --> | native_name = <!-- Company's name in home country language --> | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. If there is more than one native name, in different languages, enter those names using {{lang}}, instead. --> | type = Private<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/companies/0890282D:US-paxata|title=Paxata: Company Profile|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</ref> | industry = Enterprise analytics software | foundation = January 2012 | founder = | location_city = Redwood City, CA<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paxata.com/contact-us|title=Contact us|publisher=Paxata|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</reF> | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices, etc. --> | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{unbulleted list|Prakash Nanduri (Co-Founder & CEO)<Ref name="primaryhdah"/>|Dave Brewster (Co-Founder & CTO)<Ref name="primaryhdah"/>|Chris Maddox (Co-Founder & VP of Business Development)<Ref name="primaryhdah"/>|Nenshad Bardoliwalla (Co-Founder & Chief Product Officer)<Ref name="primaryhdah">{{cite web|url=http://www.paxata.com/paxata-leadership|title=Paxata Leadership|publisher=Paxata|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</reF>}} | products = The Paxata suite of self-service data preparation software | services = | revenue = | owner = | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.paxata.com/}} }} '''Paxata''' is a privately owned software company headquartered in [[Redwood City, California]]. It develops self-service data preparation software that gets data ready for [[data analytics]] software. Paxata's software is intended for [[business analyst]]s, as opposed to technical staff. It is used to combine data from different sources, then check it for [[data quality]] issues, such as duplicates and outliers. Algorithms and [[machine learning]] automate certain aspects of data preparation and users work with the software through a user-interface similar to [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] spreadsheets.
The company was founded in January 2012 and operated in [[stealth mode]] until October 2013. It has received more than $10 million in venture funding. Analysts have praised Paxata for creating software that is user-friendly for non-technical business users, but caution that they are in a noisy marketplace.
== History ==
Paxata was founded in January 2012.<ref name="one"/> It initially raised $2 million in venture capital.<ref name="two">{{cite news|work=Gigaom|title=With $10M from Accel, Paxata wants to make data prep a breeze|first=Derrick|last=Harris|date=October 28, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2014|url=http://gigaom.com/2013/10/28/with-10m-from-accel-paxata-wants-to-make-data-prep-a-breeze/}}</ref> The company came out of [[stealth mode]] in October 2013.<ref name="one"/> Simultaneously with its public release, Paxata announced an $8 million funding round led by Accel Partners.<ref name="one">{{cite news|title=Paxata grabs $8M to help data scientists skip the dirty work|url=http://venturebeat.com/2013/10/28/paxata-grabs-8m-to-help-data-scientists-skip-the-dirty-work/|work=VentureBeat|date=October 28, 2013|first=Eric |last=Blattberg|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="three">{{cite news|date=October 28, 2013|title=Paxata Debuts Data Quality Tools at Strata|first=Alex|last=Woodie|url=http://www.datanami.com/2013/10/28/paxata_debuts_data_quality_tools_at_strata/|work=Datanami|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> Adoption of the software grew quickly.<ref name="one"/><ref name="ten">{{cite news|title=Paxata: streamlining data analytics|first=Alan|last=McStravick|date=February 12, 2014|url=http://siliconangle.com/blog/2014/02/12/paxata-streamlining-data-analytics-bigdatasv/|work=SiliconAngle|publisher=The SiliconAngle Network|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> In March 2014, [[In-Q-Tel]] acquired an interest in the startup.<ref>{{cite news|date=March 7, 2014|title=In-Q-Tel Invests in Data-Prep Platform Paxata|url=http://www.informationweek.com/government/big-data-analytics/in-q-tel-invests-in-data-prep-platform-paxata/d/d-id/1114169|newspaper=InformationWeek|publisher=UBM Tech|accessdate=June 19, 2014|first=Patience|last=Wait}}</ref> It raised an additional $18 million in funding in September 2015.<ref name="Harris 2015">{{cite web | last=Harris | first=Derrick | title=This startup raised $18 million to make data analysis less of a chore | website=Fortune | date=September 9, 2015 | url=http://fortune.com/2015/09/09/paxata-funding-data-analysis/ | accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> It also began working with Cisco to jointly develop the Cisco Data Preparation suite of software and services.<ref name="eWeek.com 2015">{{cite web | title=Cisco Makes Move Into Data Preparation Space | website=eWeek.com | date=September 30, 2015 | url=http://www.eweek.com/networking/cisco-makes-move-into-data-preparation-space.html | accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> == Software ==
Paxata refers to its suite of cloud-based data [[data quality|quality]], [[data integration|integration]], enrichment and governance products as "Adaptive Data Preparation."<ref name="three"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Startup Paxata automates the dirty work of big data|first=Conner|last=Forrest|date=March 4, 2014|url=http://www.techrepublic.com/article/startup-paxata-automates-the-dirty-work-of-big-data/|work=TechRepublic|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=June 26, 2014}}</ref><ref name="seven"/><ref name="four">{{cite news|first=Tony|last=Baer|publisher=Ovum|title=Paxata puts a business-user face on data preparation|date=October 28, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2014|url=http://www.ovum.com/paxata-puts-a-business-user-face-on-data-preparation/}}</ref> The software is intended for [[business analyst]]s, who need to combine data from a variety of sources, then check the data for duplicates, empty fields, outliers, trends and integrity issues before conducting analysis or visualization in a third-party software tool.<ref name="four"/><ref>{{cite news|title=On the Radar: Paxata|first=Tony|last=Baer|date=December 13, 2013|accessdate=June 13, 2014|url=http://www.ovum.com/research/on-the-radar-paxata/|publisher=Ovum}}</ref> It uses algorithms and machine-learning to automate certain aspects of data preparation.<ref name="four"/><ref name="thirteen"/> For example, it may automatically detect records belonging to the same person or address, even if the information is formatted differently in each record in different data sets.<ref name="thirteen">{{cite news|date=February 11, 2014|first=Michael|last=Fitzgerald|title=Is Your Company Running a Data Dump?|url=http://www.informationweek.com/software/information-management/is-your-company-running-a-data-dump/d/d-id/1113776|newspaper=InformationWeek|publisher=UBM Tech|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="nine"/>
The software has a spreadsheet-based user interface.<ref name="four"/><ref name="nine">{{cite news|title=Paxata Give Analysts Valuable Time Back for Analytics|date=January 29, 2014|url=http://tonycosentino.ventanaresearch.com/2014/01/29/paxata-give-analysts-valuable-time-back-for-analytics/|accessdate=June 19, 2014 |first=Tony|last=Cosentino|publisher=Ventana Research}}</ref> Patterns and anomalies in the data are color-coded in the spreadsheet. Then users are provided with instructions on how to resolve data quality issues or to supplement the data with contextual information.<ref name="seven">{{cite news|title=Cool Vendors in Data Integration and Data|date=April 24, 2014|first1=Eric|last1=Thoo|first2=Ted|last2=Friedman|first3=Saul|last3=Judah|first4=Rita L.|last4=Sallam|first5=Roxane|last5=Edjlali|publisher=Gartner|url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/2719217/cool-vendors-data-integration-data|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> Data sets and related quality issues can also be addressed in a collaborative environment through the "Paxata Share" feature.<ref name="nine"/> It runs on [[Apache Spark]].<ref name="Harris 2015"/><ref>{{cite web | title=Paxata Applies Data Governance Controls to Big Data | website=IT Business Edge | date=April 23, 2015 | url=http://www.itbusinessedge.com/blogs/it-unmasked/paxata-applies-data-governance-controls-to-big-data.html | accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref>
According to analyst firm [[Ovum Ltd.|Ovum]], the software is made possible through advances in [[predictive analytics]], [[machine learning]] and the [[NoSQL]] data caching methodology.<ref name="four"/> The software uses [[Semantics|semantic]] algorithms to understand the meaning of a data table's columns and pattern recognition algorithms to find potential duplicates in a data-set.<ref name="four"/><ref name="two"/> It also uses indexing, text pattern recognition and other technologies traditionally found in social media and search software.<ref name="six">{{cite news|title=Automating the Pain Out of Big Data Transformation|first=Alex|last=Woodie|url=http://www.datanami.com/2014/01/24/automating_the_pain_out_of_big_data_transformation/|accessdate=June 19, 2014|date=January 24, 2014|work=Datanami}}</ref> One of the software's users is dairy producer [[Dannon]], which uses the software so that business staff can create their own reports on merchandising, supply chain and product data, without the IT department.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.baselinemag.com/business-intelligence/dannon-speeds-up-data-preparation-and-analysis.html/|title=Dannon Speeds Up Data Preparation and Analysis|date=March 26, 2014|first=Eileen|last=Feretic|newspaper=Baseline|publisher=Bradbourne Publishing|accessdate=June 22, 2014 }}</ref>
[[File:Paxata-screenshot.png|thumb|center|700px|Paxata's spreadsheet-based user interface]]
== Reception ==
In its 2014 report "Cool Vendors in Data Integration and Data Quality", [[Gartner]] praised Paxata for developing a "business-user-friendly" data quality product that does not use code.<ref name="seven"/> Ventana Research said its spreadsheet-based user interface "should resonate well with business analysts," who are resistant to move away from familiar Excel-like programs.<ref name="nine"/> Gartner also said Paxata was recognized in the report due to its automated, algorithm-based features and how it tracks any changes made to the data.<ref name="seven"/>
Ventana Research said Paxata was in a "noisy marketplace".<ref name="nine"/> According to Gartner, while Paxata is an early entrant into the market, many startups and large corporations are making investments in developing similar competing products.<ref name="seven"/> According to ''[[Gigaom]]'' and ''IT Business Edge'', one way Paxata differs is that it automatically merges multiple data-sets into a single table, so it can be easily imported into a visualization or analysis tool.<ref name="two"/><ref name="five">{{cite news|title=Paxata Rises to the Challenge of Big Data Preparation|first=Mike|last=Vizard|date=November 27, 2013|url=http://www.itbusinessedge.com/blogs/it-unmasked/paxata-rises-to-the-challenge-of-big-data-preparation.html|work=IT Business Edge|publisher=QuinStreet|accessdate=June 19, 2014}} </ref>
Gartner said Paxata will have a difficult time finding a compelling pricing model, when many data discovery tools that it supplements provide some similar features.<ref name="seven"/> In contrast, Ventana said Paxata's pricing was "a pretty small amount" compared to the amount of time users can save.<ref name="nine"/>
